column4: Hi, how would I cause a program to shut up and go into the background (so I can put it in rc,local)?
How can I execute a program/script into the background and make it quiet?
You mean run it in the background?  ./script &
Yeah, but how do I silence all output?
I want to put it in rc.local so I dont want any weird crap coming through
Well, you can always send all its stdout and stderr off to La-La Land: ./script &> /dev/nulll &
I think erUSUL's syntax only works through a pipe.. have you tried that erUSUL?
Will your method make *all* output die?
Yes, all stdin and stderr get thrown into cyberspace: /dev/null  :)
Huh? It won't hang the bash shell.
Yes, and be careful what you put in it because everything is run as root.
If you don't need your script run as root, add it with the "Sessions" program to run on startup.
Sessions will run the script under the user who logs in.
OK, yes I think that should work, try it at the command line to make sure you get everything right.
Good deal, hopefully your set to go.
